Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to specified amounts from fiscal year 1996 onwards. The agreement between the United States and the Northern Mariana Islands, signed in 1992, includes provisions for additional funding beyond what is specified in the agreement. These additional amounts are to be made available for obligation by the Secretary in fiscal year 1996. The additional amounts specified in subsection (b) are to be used for capital infrastructure projects in various territories, including American Samoa, Guam, the Virgin Islands, the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, with an additional $3 million annually for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands, including detention and corrections needs. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a five-year plan for infrastructure assistance in the Northern Mariana Islands, focusing on detention and corrections needs, in consultation with island governments and Congress. The Secretary will prioritize capital infrastructure projects, considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance needs, local cost-share capabilities, and proposing a $2 million annual set-aside. The Secretary may propose a $2 million annual set-aside for an emergency fund to supplement assistance in repairing essential facilities in case of disasters, with a cumulative limit of $10 million. Additional contributions for infrastructure projects can be made within the allocated amounts. The Appropriation Acts allow for additional contributions up to $32 million for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, subject to certain conditions. The funds must be used solely for resettlement activities and be properly audited. The Appropriation Acts allow for up to $32 million in contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, to be used solely for resettlement activities and properly audited. Federal agencies can provide funds through the Secretary of the Interior for this purpose. Ex gratia assistance may also be provided under certain conditions. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 allows for assistance for individuals not resettling at Rongelap, contingent on full funding for resettlement being provided first. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with minimum wage rates set at $2.75 per hour initially, increasing to $3.05 per hour on January 1, 1996. The minimum wage rate applicable to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands shall be $3.05 per hour, increasing by thirty cents per hour annually until it reaches the wage rate set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it reaches that level, the minimum wage rate will remain the same. The minimum wage rate for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be the same as the wage rate in the Fair Labor Standards Act. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each fiscal year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities. The report includes immigration data, such as the number of non-U.S. citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior includes data on non-U.S. citizen contract workers in the CNMI, treatment conditions, foreign government interference, laws' effect on Federal interests, and detention facilities adequacy. The report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior addresses the impact of laws in the Northern Mariana Islands on Federal interests, the adequacy of detention facilities, the reliability of the alien identification system, and reasons for federal agencies' enforcement challenges without funding. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within the CNMI waters and exclusive economic zone of the United States. Aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands can work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels in the CNMI waters and exclusive economic zone of the United States. Amendments allow them to be employed in the US under specific conditions. Ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands clarified. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections previously mentioning Guam and the Virgin Islands. Amendment to Public Law 93-435 includes the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands along with Guam and the Virgin Islands in certain sections. The amendment changes references to the date of enactment to align with the date of enactment of the new section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, employment, and administrative capabilities. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to replace "the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands" with "the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia." Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
